Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story:
I sat at the edge of the couch, half-listening as my stepdad tossed out ideas for the weekend—maybe a picnic, maybe the water park. My stepsister nudged me, her eyes bright, clearly hoping I’d back her up on the water park plan. I knew Mom wanted us all to chime in, to feel like a real family, so I tried to sound enthusiastic, even though my mind kept drifting to my lifeguard shift later that day.

At the pool, the air was thick with chlorine and laughter. I scanned the water, my whistle ready. Suddenly, I spotted a group of teenagers—my stepsister among them—gathered at the deep end, giggling as they lined up near the “No Diving” signs. My supervisor’s words echoed in my head: “No exceptions. Safety first.” But my stepsister caught my eye, grinning, clearly expecting me to let it slide, just this once, in front of her new friends. My heart pounded as I weighed the rules I was sworn to uphold against the fragile trust I was still building at home.
